bibl.title: Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part II).
bibl.author: David Livingstone

div.p:
XVI - 1 5
On questioning intelligent men
among the Bakwains as to their
former ideasknowledge of good and
evil, of God & the future state
they have scouted the idea
idea of any of them ever
having been without a
tolerably clear conception ofon
all these subjects them all - Respecting
the former they profess that
nothing we indicate as sin
ever appeared to them ˄ as otherwise new
except the statement that it
was wrong to have more
wives than one - And they
declare they spoke in the
same way of the direct influence
exercised by God in giving
rain in answer to prayers
of the rainmakers and in
granting deliverance in times
of delive danger as they dowdo
now before they
ever heard of
white men - The want however
of any form of public worship
or of idols or of formal
prayers or sacrifice makes
both Caffres and Bechuanas
appear as among the most
godless ˄ races of mortals known
anywhere.

2 6
Leaving Motlatsa on the 8th
January we passed away
down the Mokoko which
in the memory of persons
now living was a flowing
stream - We ourselves once
saw a heavy thunder shower
make it assume its ancient
appearance of running to the
North - Between Lotlakani &
Nchokotsa we pass the small
well named Orapa Thutsa
Orapa & another ncalled Thutsa
the water is salt and purgative
The salt pan Chuantsa having
a cake ˄ of salt 1₁/₂1/2 inches in thickness diameter of salt
is about 10 miles to the N- E-North East of
Orapa This saltdeposit contains
a bitter, salt in addition,
probably the sulphate ˄ nitrate of
lime the natives in order
to render it palatable & wholesome
mix the salt with a^ the juice of a gummy
plant - Then place it in the
sand and bake it by
making a fire over it
The lime then becomes deprived
of its sulphate and is insoluble
and tastlesstasteless

3 7
The Bamangwato keep large
flocks of sheep and goats at
various spots on this side of
the desert They thrive wonderfully
well wherever salt & bushes
are to be found - The milk
of goats does not coagulate
with facility like that of cows
on account of its richness
but the natives have discovered
that the infusion of the fruit
of a solanaceous plant
quickly produces the effect
The Bechuanas put their
milk into leathern sacks
made of untanned hide with
the hair taken off - Hung in
the sun it soon coagulates
whey the way whey is then drawn off
by a plug at the bottom
& fresh milk added untilluntil
the whole is sack is full
of a thick sour curd which
when one becomes used to
it is delicious - The Rich mix
this in the porridge into which
they covert their meal - and
as it is thus nutritious and
strength giving the ˄ an expression
of scorn is sometimes
heard respecting the poor or
weak ^ to the effect that "they are mere
water porridge men - It
occupies the place of our Roast beef
4 8
15 We procuredAt Nchokotsa - Thise rainy season
having this year beingen delayed
beyond the usual time we found
the thermometer during the day stand at 96° in the coolest
possible shade - This height at Kolobeng
always portended rains at
hand - At Kuruman when
it rises above 84° the same
phenomenon may be considered
near - While farther North
it rises upwards of 100° before
the cooling influence of the
evaporation by rain falling
may be expected - Here the
bulb of the thermometer placed
two inches beneath the soil
stood at 128° - All around Nchokotsa
the country looked parched and
the glare from the white efflorescence
which covers the extensive
pans all around us iswas most
distressing to the eyes - The
water of Nchokotsa was bitter
and presented indications
not to be mistaken of having
passed through animal systems
before - All these waters contain
nitrates which stimulate the
kidneys and increase the
thirst - The additions of fresh
water required in cooking
f meat render by imparting
greater quantities of salt
make one grumble at the
5 9
the cook for putting too much
seasoning in and findwhilst in
that ˄ fact he has put in none at
all ^ except that
contained in
the water Of bitter bad disgusting
waters I have drank not a few
nauseous draughts - you may
try alum, vitriol, boiling, &c &c
to convince yourself that you
are not more stupid than
travellers you will meet at home
but the ammonia & other salts
are there still - and the only remedy
is to get away as quickly
as possible to the North -

We dug out several
wells and as we had on
each occasion of the sort
to wait till the water flowed
in - ,& then allow our cattle
to feed a/daya day or two and
slake their thirst thoroughly
as far as that could be done
before starting, - our progress
was ˄ but slow - At Koobe there
was such a mass of mud
^ in the pond
worked up by
the wallowing
Rhinoceros
to the consistency
of mortar that only by great labour
could we get a space cleared
forat one side for the water
to soak in for the oxen - Should
another Rhinoceros come back
a single roll in the great
mass we had thrown on
one side would have
rendered all our labour vain
6 10
It was therefore necessary for
us to gauuard the spot by night
On those great flats all around
we seeaw in the ˄ white sultry glare herds
of zebras - gnus & occasionally
buffaloes standing for days
looking wistfully to the wells
for a share of the nasty water -
Now to take advantage of the
necessities of these poor animals
and shoot ˄ them down one after
another without maintending
to make the smallest use
of their ca either the ˄ flesh skins or horns
is mere wanton cruelty - ˄ In Firing
by night, animals are more
frequently wounded than killed
The flowing life stream increases
the thirst so that they comes
slowly up to drink inespitein spite
of the danger, "I must drink
though I die" The ostrich --
even when unwounded cannot
with all his wariness resist
the excessive desire to slake
his burning thirst - It is a
bushmanBushman practice to take
advantage of its piteous
necessities for most of the
feathers they bringobtain are procured
in this way - but they eat
the flesh and are so far
justifiable - justified

When I would not order
7 11
my men to do what I would
not do myself - but though I tried
to justify myself on the plea
of necessity I could not
descend to this mean sneaking
and cowardly mode of hunting ^
even for the
object named ^ You are said to be in a hole
watching for the game and
if for ^ your object is to securinge the best
specimens ˄ for a museum, it may be allowable
but if, as is generally the case
when ^ this mode is practised by whites Englishmen
great numbers of animalss are wounded &
alowedallowed to perish merismiser-ably
in the distance or are killed on
the spot ^ in both cases only and left ^ to be preyed on by
vultures and hyaenashyenas -
and all ^ ^ for the sole purpose of making
a "bag" ˄ then I take to it to be evidence
that such sportsmen of the individual being
are pretty far gone in the hunting
form of insanity - Every
true hunter considers detests this cowardly way
of "bagging" - as unfair except
in cases of lions or tigers -
They think all other animals
entitled to a fair stand up
fight - The hole in this case
as I have often observed is
actually a cavity but that
Qu:Query this word? which is wanting awanting in all
the pictures of it, is a wall
of stones ^ surmounted by a hedge of
"wait a bit" thorns through
which no animal will
8 12
even attempt to pass - All have
a great dread of this thorn
in addition to their fear of
everything like trap or
pitfall so he who is
coward enough to butcher
common animals from
his lair of perfect safety
resembles not a huntsman
but a common hangman
with a mask on - The
hedge is left out in the pictures
for the same reason probably
that Jack Ketch in getting
his portrait taken would
leave out his bit of crape -

My men shot a black
Rhinoceros in this disreputable
way, and I felt glad to get
away from the only place
in which I ˄ ever had any share
in hangman hunting - We
passed over the immense
pan Ntwetwe on which
the latitude could be taken as
at sea - Great tracts of
this part of the country are
of calcareous tufa with
only a thin coating of soil
Numbers of Baobab and
Mopane trees abound here all
over this hard smooth surface -
Of The former named MouanaMowana
we unyoked under a fine
9 13
specimen dAbout two miles
from the Northern bank of the
pan, we unyoked
under a fine
specimen of the
former class,
called MouanaMowana consisting of six branches
united into one bole - At three
feet from the ground it iswas 85 ftfeet
in circumference

These Mowana trees are the
most wonderful examples of
vitality in the country - It was
therefore with surprise that
we came upon a dead one
at Tlomtla a few miles
beyond this ˄cspot - It is the same as
those which Adanson and
others believed, from specimens
seen in Western Africa, to
have been alive before
the flood, And "that therefore"
(in consequence ofArguing with a particular
mental idiosyncrasy resembling
colour blindness common
among the French of the time)
these savans came
to the conclusion
that "therefore there never was any flood
at all" - I would back
a true MoanaMowana against two
a dozen floods provided you do not
boil it in hot sea water &
(Omit - as
not necessary) yet believe most firmly that
there was a flood because
the bible says it - The natives
make a strong cord from
the fibres contained in the
pounded bark - The whole
of the trunk, as high as distance they can reach
to is thereforeconsequently often quite
10 14
denuded of its covering
which in the case of
almost every other tree would
cause its death but this
has no effect on the MoanaMowana
except to cause it to throw
out a new onebark which is
done in the way of granulation
This process of denudation
is repeated - frequently and
it is common to see
the diameter of the lower
five or six feet an inch
or two less than the parts
above - Even partsportions of the
bark which in being taken
off break but remain
above where
the knife
could reach detached from the parts
abovebelow continue to grow
and resemble closely marks
made in the necks of the
cattle of Mull - where in which
a piece of skin is detached
and allowed to hang down
No external injury, not
even a fire, can destroy
this tree it from without - Nor
can any injury be done
from within for it is
quite common to find
them hollow and I have
seen one in which twenty
or thirty men could lie
down and sleep as in
a hut -
11 15
Nor does cutting down exterminate
it either - for I saw instances
in Angola in which it
continued to grow in length
after it was lying on
the ground - The reason
is each ˄ of the laminae possesses
independent vitality - In fact
it is more a gigantic
bulb than a run up to
seed than a tree - Each of
84 concentric rings had
in the case mentioned
grown an inch sinceafter
the tree had been
felled
blown over it assumed the prone
position - The roots which
may often be observed
extending to run along the surface ˄ of the ground
forty or 50 yards from
the trunk also retain their
vitality after the tree is
laid low and the Portuguese
now know that the
best way to treat them
is to let them alone for
they occupy much more
room when cut down
than when growing

The wood is so spongy
and soft that an axe can
be struck in so far with a
good blow, that there is
great more difficulty in pulling
it out than in the act of
inserting it -
12 16
In the dead MoanaMowana mentioned
the concentric rings were
well seen - The average of
for a foot at three different places
was 81 ₁/₂1/2 inches lamellae - Each
of these rings can be seen to
be composed of 2, 3 - or 4
oflayers> of ligneous tubes
but supposing each ring
the growth of one year
then a MoanaMowana of 100 feet
in circumference would
be about 500 years old

Though it possessees amazing
vitality it is difficult to
believe that this great baby
looking bulb or tree is as
old as the pyramids -

13 17
The Mopane
is remarkable for the little shade
its leaves afford - They fold
together and stand nearly
perpendicular during the heat
of the day - so that only the
shadow of their edges comes
to the ground - On these leaves
the small larvae of a lwinged
insect appears covered over
with a sweet gummy substance
The people collect this in
great quantities and use it
as food - And the lopane -
a large caterpillars which
are seen strung together -
share suffer the same fate -
In passing along we see
every-where the power of
vegetation in breaking
up the outer crust of of
tufa - A Mopane tree mal
growing uin a small chink
as it increases in size
rends and lifts up large
fragments of the rock all
around it ^ subjecting them to the disintegrating
influence of the atmosphere
14 18
The wood is
hard, and
of a fine
red colour
and is
named by
the Portuguese
iron wood The inhabitants observing
that the Mopane is more
frequently struck by lightning
than others^ trees caution travellers
never to seek its shade
when a thunder storm is
near - "Lightning it" hates it" -
while another ˄ tree - the "Marala"
- which havehas three spines opposite
each other - having never
been touched by this agentlightning
is esteemed even as far as
Angola as a protection
against the electric fluid -
branchesBranches of it may be seen
placed on the houses of the
Portuguese for the same
purpose reason - And the natives
believe that an elephant
a man is thoroughly
protected from an enraged
elephant if he can
get into itsthe shade ˄ of this tree - There
may not be much in
this but there is frequently
some foundation of
substratum of truth in
their observations

15 15 19
At Rapesh we came among
our old friends the Bushmen
X QuQuery meaning
who? under ˄ of ˄ under Horoye - This ˄ Xman Horoye a specimen of
that tribe as well as his sonsand his son Mokantsa
& others were at least 6 ftfeet high and
of a darker colour than
the Bushmen of the South
They have always plenty of
food and water and as
they frequent the Zouga as do
the game in company with
whom they live - Theyir life
is very different from
that of those who live
on the thirsty plains of the
Kalahari - The animal they
refrain from eating is
the goat which fact mentioned
by Mokantsa is proof of
their hatred of domestic
animals - They are a merry
laughing set and do not tell
lies wantonly - They have
in their superstitions observances
more appearance of worship
than the Bechuanas and
at a bushmanBushman's grave we
once came to on the Zouga
the observances shewedshowed distinctly
that they regarded the dead as
still in another state of being
for they address him ˄ and request
him not to be offended though
they wish still to remain a
little while longer here in this world -

16 16 20
Those among whom we now
were kill many elephants
and when the moon is
full choose that ˄ time for the
chase on account of its
coolness - Hunting this
QuQuery sport animal is the best test of courage this
country affords - The Bushmen
choose the moment succeeding
a charge when the elephant he is out of
breath to run in and give
him a stab with their long
bladed spears - In this case
the uncivilized have the
advantage over us but
I believe that with half their
training Englishmen would
beat the Bushmen - Our
present form of civilization
does not necessarily produce
effeminacy though it
unquestionably increases
both the beauty courage and
physical powers ˄ of the race - When at
Kolobeng I took notes of the
different numbers of elephants
killed in the course of the
season by the various parties
ofwhich went past our dwelling
in order to form an idea
of the probable annual annual destruction of
this noble animal - There were
parties of Boers - Griquas
Bechuanas ˄ Boers and Englishmen
17 21
As all were eager from to
distinguish themselves and
success depends mainly on
the courage which leads
the huntsman to go close to
the animal and not waste
the force of thehis shot byon the
air - It was noticeable
that the average for the natives
was under one per man
for the Griquas one per man
for the Boers two and
for the Englishman Officers 20 each
who hunted elephants - This
was the more remarkable as
the Griquas Boers & Bechuanas
employed both dogs and
natives to assist them
while the Englishmen
generally had none of assistance
from either - They went
approached to aboutwithin 30 yards from
the animal while the others
stood at ˄ a distance of - 100 yards or even
more and of course spent
all the force of their bullets
on the air - One elephant
was found by Mr OswelOswell
with quite a crowd of
bullets in his side fired
in this style and they had
not gone near the vital
parts

18 22
It would thus appear that
Ourour more barbarous neighbours
do not possess ˄ thus not half the courage
of the civilized ˄ sportsman - And it is
probable that in this respect
as well as in physical
development we are
superior to our ancestors -
theThe coats of mail & greaves
of the Knights of Malta and
the armour from the Tower
exhibited at the Eglinton
tournament may be
considered decisive on the
question of the greater size
attained by modern civilised
man

At Maila we spent a Sunday
with Kaisa the headman
of a village of Mashona whichwho
had fled from the iron sway
of MosilikatzeMosilikatse whose country
lies eEast of this - I wished him
to take charge of a packet of
letters for home to be delivered
when as is the custom of the
Bamangwato the Bechuanas
come here in search of skins
and food among the Bushmen
But he could not be made
to comprehend that there was no
danger in them - He feared
the responsibility thand guilt
if any thinganything should happen to them
19 23
so I had to bid adieu to all hope
of letting my family hear of my
welfare till I should reach
the West coast -

At Unku we came into a
tract of country which had been
visited by refreshing showers
long before and every spot
was covered with grass run
up to seed and the flowers
of the forest were in full blowbloom
Instead of the cheery prospect
around Koobe & Nchokotsa
we had now a delightful
scene - all the ponds full
of water - & the birds twittering
joyfully - As the game can
now find water everywhere
they become very shy and
cannot be found in their
accustomed haunts -

1st March thermometer in
the shade generally 98° at ˄ from one to 3 P.M.
but it sinks as low as 65° by
night - so it is not exhausting
heat - The surface of the ground
125° and three inches below it
138° - The hand cannot be
held on it and even the
horny soles ˄ of the feet of the natives
must be protected by sandals
of hide yet the ants were
busy working on it - The
water in the ponds rises
20 24
up to one 100° but as ˄ itwater does
not conduct heat readily
downwards deliciously cool
water may be obtained by
any one walking into the middle and
lifting up the water to the
surface with the hands -

Proceeding to the North
from Kama Kama we entered
into dense to Mohonono bush
which required the constant
application of the axe by three
of our party for two days
This bush has fine silvery
leaves and the bark has a
sweet taste - The Elephant
with his usuall nicety ^ delicacy of taste ^ feeds
much on it - On emerging on to
the plains beyond we found
a number of bushmenBushmen who
afterwards proved very serviceable
The rains had been copious
and great numbers of pools
were now drying up - Lotus
plants abounded in them and
a low sweet scented plant
coversed their banks - Breezes
came occasionally to us
from these drying up pools
but the
pleasant odour
they carryied causesd
sneezing in both
myself and people and on the 10th March we
were brought to a stand by
four of the party being seized
with fever (LatLatitude 19° 16' 11" South LongLongitude 24° 24' East)
21 25
As I was then unacquainted with
the African fever I imagined
it was chiefly only a bilious attack
arising from full feeding
on flesh the large game
having been very abundant
we always had a good
supply but instead of the
first party recovering soon
every man of the party was
in a few days laid low
except a Bakwain lad and
myself - He managed the oxen
while I attended to the wants
of the patients and went out
occasionally with the Bushmen
to get a Zebra or buffalo so as
to induce them to remain
with us - The grass here was
so tall ˄ that the oxen became uneasy
and one night the sight of a
hyaenahyena made them rush away
into the forest to the East of us
On rising in the morning of the
19th I found that Kibopechoe
my Bakwain lad had raun away
with them - This I have often
seen with persons of this tribe
even when the cattle are startled
by a lion Away go the young
men in company with them
and dash through bush and
brake for miles till they
think the panic is a little
22 26
subsided, they then commence
whistling whitling to them the cattle in the manner
they do when milking the cows
And having calmed them they remain
as a gauuard till the morning
The oxenmen They generally return with
their shins well peeled by
the thorns - Each comrade
of the Mopato mopato would
expect his fellow to act thus
without expecting ˄ looking for any other more
reward than ˄ the praise fromof the chief
Our lad Kibopechoe had gone after them
the oxen but had lost them in the
rush away through the
trackless flat forest and
He remained on their trail all ˄ the next
day and all ˄ the next night - On
Sunday morning as I was
setting off in search of him
I found him near the waggon
He had found ˄ themthe oxen late in
the afternoon and ˄ had been obliged
to stand by them all night
HeIt was wonderful that
how he managed without ˄ a compass & in such
a country he foundto find his
way ^ home at all withbringing about
forty oxen with him -

23 27
The Bechuanas keep on
the sick list as long as they
feel any weakness so I ˄ at last began
to be anxious that they should
make a little exertion for a
to get forward
on our way. movement One of them however
happen^eding to move a hundred
yards from the waggon and
being unobserved fell down
and remained totally insensible
the whole night during a in the pouring rain the
whole night - Another was
subjected to frequent swooning
but making beds for these
our worst cases I with the
help of the Bakwain and
the Bushmen moved slowly
on - We had to nurse the sick
like children And like children
recovering from illness the
better they became the more
impudent they grew - This was
seen in the peremptory orders
they would give with their
now piping voices - Nothing
that we did could pleased
them and the laughter with which
I recievedreceived their ebullitions
though it was theonly the reallreal expression
of gladness at their recovery
and amusement at the ridiculous
part they acted only increased
their chagrin - The bad
leading we had l caused us
24 28
to be entangled with trees both standing
and fallen and
made the labour inof cutting
them down ˄ was even much more
severe than ordinarily but
notwithstanding an
immense amount of toil
my health continued good

We We wished to avoid
the Tsetse of our former
path so kept a course
on the magnetic meridian
from Lurilopepe - This
making a new path was
the reason of so much
much increased our more toil - We were however
rewarded in 18° with the a sight
sight of we had not enjoyed
the year before, namely of large
patches of grape bearing vines
There they stood before my
eyes but the ideasight seemed
so was so entirely unexpected
that I stood some-time gazing
at them with no, the clusters
of grapes with which they
were loaded that as if I
with no more
thought of
acting than
if I had been beholding them in
a dream - The Bushmen
know and eat them - but
they are not good on account
of the great sizeastringency of the seeds
which are in shape and
size like split peas The
elephants are fond of both
the fruit, plant, and root alike
